p: The earliest report on NASICON-type Mg 2+ conductor came from Ikeda in 1987, who studied the system of Mg-Zr-PO 4 in various molar ratios as Mg ion conductor using mechanochemical synthesis (Ikeda et al., 1987). Among them, MgZr 4(PO 4) 6 (MZP) showed the highest conductivity of 2.9 × 10 −5 and 6.1 × 10 −3 S cm −1 at 400 and 800°C, respectively. The Tubandt's method and the electron probe microanalysis were used to confirm the charge carrier to be Mg ions. According to X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements, the author simply claimed that the crystal structure of MZP similar to NaZr 2(PO 4) 3, resulted in the best conductivity relative to analogs with other ratios, while no further evidence was provided in the report.
